Doug-

Ono-no-tofu. Big thanks.
   The second story actually fits with the tsuba I
saw. The frog is in motion across the tsuba towards or
up an incline. The smiling man overlooking the frog is
positioned in the background, with the incline
covering part of his legs. He's obviously watching the
frog.

Curran



--- douglas sanders <dhs1us@...> wrote:
> There are two stories where frogs (or toads) crop
> up, that I know of, in Japanese imagery.  One is
> with Gama Senin- a mythical sage who is often seen
> with a toad on his shoulder.  Sort of his
> familiar.
> The other is the story of Ono-no-tofu, whereby a
> would-be civil servant is encouraged to try once
> again at taking his exams after watching a frog
> perservere in his attempts to jump out of a pond,
> up a steep bank.  A frog could therefore be seen as
> a symbol of perserverance.  
> 
> 
> -Doug Sanders
> >    At the same time I saw these two odd-guys, I
> saw a
> > tsuba with another stylized frog / toad wearing a
> > similar quirked expression. An wise man or priest
> was
> > standing in the backgound overlooking the frog
> with a
> > jovial look on his face.
> >    I did no know if there was a story here. Other
> than
> > Kermit, I'm not too fond of frogs.
> > 
> > Curran
> > 
> > 
> >
